Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2012 05:28PM jenn333 wrote: ER 95%, PR 98%.  Oncotype 14 (9% chance of recurrence).  No chemo. My onc told me that she can predict whether onco will be high or low by looking at ER%, PR%, KI67% and grade.  She was right with me.
Posts.Title: Another Oncotype question mary71 Scarlet2

Posts.Content: May 28, 2012 07:46AM jenn333 wrote: Bluepearl - my UCLA MO said that a high PR was a good thing to have as it indicated a less aggressive cancer. So, it seems like what we want for a low Oncotype score is ER and PR as high as possible and KI67 and grade as low as possible. My MO claims to be able to predict Oncotype scores (low, intermediate or high at least) with just these four factors. I would think HER2+ would automatically give a higher score but we didn't discuss that since I'm HER2-.
Posts.Title: Another Oncotype question mary71 Scarlet2

Posts.Content: May 31, 2012 02:16PM jenn333 wrote: You have to ask your surgeon or MO to order the test for you.  As a rough rule of thumb, it seems that high ER/PR, together with low grade and low Ki67 generally correlates with a low score unless you're HER2+.
Posts.Title: Another Oncotype question mary71 Scarlet2

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2012 06:05AM - edited Jun 1, 2012 09:53AM by jenn333 From what I've read, any ER% is ER+ and is responsive to Tamoxifen.  The Oncotype score will give you your ER/PR percentages and, I think, your Ki67.  I would ask my MO to order the Oncotype test.  It will tell you if chemo will be of any benefit to you.

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2012 08:51AM jenn333 wrote: Do you have a copy of the pathology report on the FNA?  "It looks to be" and "assumed to be" don't sit well with me.  My initial FNAs showed "atypical cells" but not an outright finding of cancer.  We did a core biopsy at the same time as the FNAs on a mass that had vascular flow and so was highly suspicious for malignancy.  (Turned out to be IDC.)  The FNAs were done on a couple of smaller tumors that looked less suspicious.  When the core biopsy result was in, radiologist called for a second look ultrasound and did two additional core biopsies on the masses that the FNAs had been done on.  They turned out to be IDC too.  So much for the FNAs as a diagnostic tool (in my case, at least). In your shoes, I would not let enlarged nodes and these other issues just sit for 3 months.  I'd be asking for a core biopsy of the nodules you know about and a definitive finding on what's going on with the nodes.  Then when you have the results of the biopsy and whatever tests they can do on the nodes, I'd push for an MRI post haste.  Trust your gut. Don't mean to scare you but I think you have a couple of significant red flags that you need to rule out. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Biopsy report...preliminary vs final Sjones81 ConnieGreene

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2012 12:54PM jenn333 wrote: I had to have a reexcision and I had a mastectomy.  Second time was a charm.  I did have radiation as a result though just to be on the safe side.
Posts.Title: getting clear margins from re-excision christina0001 jazlaumir

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2012 12:43PM jenn333 wrote: I don't want to alarm you but I think you should pursue this.  My BC presented as a dimple but the mass (or masses, as it turned out on final pathology) couldn't be seen with a mammogram and an ultrasound only showed part of the picture.  I have (had) very dense breasts too.  You need an MRI.  I would pay for it out of pocket if you can.  Dimples don't appear for no reason.  Hopefully the reason is innocuous but you have to be sure.

Posts.Title: second opinion myboysmom3 CoolBreeze

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2012 04:40PM jenn333 wrote: Hi Soleil - I live in Orange County and had my surgeries (UMX and DIEP reconstruction) done at UCLA.  Fabulous, fabulous surgeons.  When it came time to find an oncologist, I first saw Dr. Sarah Hurvitz at UCLA in Santa Monica.  She was absolutely wonderful but because of the frequency of oncology appointments asked if I would like to attend their Irvine office which was much more conveniently located to me.  I see Dr. Merry Tetef at UCLA Irvine and love her. FYI Hoag is not an integrated center like UCLA.  The doctors just have privileges at the hospital but have offices elsewhere.  I was planning on being treated at Hoag (loved the breast surgeon) but could not find an in-network plastic surgeon to do my DIEP, hence my self-referral to UCLA.  Glad it worked out that way as it happens.  UCLA, with its multidisciplinary team, provides much more coordinated care than the patchwork team you have to put together yourself at facilities such as Hoag.  I can't speak highly enough of my UCLA experience (and this is from someone who hates LA with a passion). Hope this helps.  Feel free to PM me with any questions. Jenn

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2012 03:32PM jenn333 wrote: Crap is right. So sorry but you're in good company if that's any comfort. About what to tell the kids and your mom, we waited until we had the path results and had spoken with the surgeon. I was able to preface the conversation with my mom by saying "the first thing you need to know is I'm going to be fine" and then I let her know what's going on. I just didn't see the point in telling her before I had solid information to share about my prognosis, etc. She's a worrier and would have given herself a migraine. My daughter is only 7 so I told her I had to have an operation on my chest. I have previously had two hip resurfacing surgeries so surgery is not scary for her. I didn't have to have chemo though. Obviously that's a whole other conversation because she would have noticed the side effects, naturally. As it is, she's pretty much oblivious to it all. You'll know much more after your meeting with the surgeon. Hang in there, it gets better I promise.
